Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Lisa Jung of the University of Colorado at Boulder to conduct a research project, entitled "Exploring reproduction of an invertebrate filter feeder, the lancelet," during the summer of 2012 at Institute of Cellular and Organismic Biology in Taipei, Taiwan with host scientist Dr. Jr-Kai Yu.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to explore hormone-signaling pathways that regulate reproduction in the lancelet. Lancelet is an important animal for studying vertebrate evolution because it serves as a missing link between invertebrates and vertebrates and it closely resembles the ancestor that gave rise to the vertebrates. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is a crucial neuropeptide for regulating reproduction in vertebrates. Establishing the presence of a GnRH signaling pathway in this animal is the focus of this research and can provide undeniable proof that vertebrate GnRH and protostomian GnRH are, in fact, related and that GnRH is an ancient peptide that arose before the divergence of protostomes and deuterostomes.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to foster international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware American scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) is a hormone that plays an important role in regulating reproduction in vertebrates. Upon release from the brain, GnRH activates protein molecules (GnRH-receptors) present on certain cells of the pituitary and it indirectly regulates proper development of the gonads (ovaries and testes) and ensures proper production of sex steroid hormones and reproductive cells( sperm and eggs) necessary for fertility.  Reproductive consequence of activating GnRH receptors has been well documented in vertebrates. However, it is currently unclear whether reproductive activation by GnRH receptor signaling is conserved in invertebrate animals. 

In 2009, four GnRH receptors capable of binding vertebrate and invertebrate GnRHs have been identified in a marine invertebrate, amphioxus (Branchiostoma floridae)(Tello etal.,2009). To date, little is known about the reproductive consequence of activating GnRH receptors of amphioxus. The present study aimed to examine whether activating GnRH receptors with synthetic vertebrate GnRH 1 and 2, aplysia GnRH(ap-GnRH), and insect metabolic hormone adipokinetic hormone(AKH) would result in accelerated gonadal maturation of amphioxus. 

A total of 180 sexually immature animals were collected from Dr. Jr-Kai Yu’s amphioxus culture facility (Institute of organismic biology, Academia Sinica. Taipei Taiwan) during early July through mid-August, 2012.  The animals were immersed in natural seawater treated with three concentrations (10μg/100ml, 50μg/100ml, 100μg/100ml) of GnRH1, GnRH2, ap-GnRH, or AKH for seven days to determine whether different doses of these hormones could accelerate gonadal maturation.  The state of reproductive maturation of an animal is determined by the increased gonadal height and fullness (density). Animals’ gonads were photographed before and after treatment. The measurements of gonadal height and density were obtained before and after hormone treatment via imaging software.

Statistical analysis performed on the measurements of gonadal height and density revealed that ap-GnRH had a significant effect on accelerating gonadal maturation of amphioxus.  This study sheds a light on exciting possibility that an invertebrate form of GnRH (ap-GnRH) may have an ability to activate GnRH-Rs in amphioxus and that activation of GnRH-R results in acceleration of gonadal development. Our results indicate that reproductive activation by GnRH-R signaling seen in vertebrates may be conserved in a vertebrate ancestor, amphioxus.
